le jeu qui est la base du jeu de tir qui ma tout appris, la preuve je suis dans l'armée de terre, bon blague à part mais vrais tu peux ps courrir non stoppe comme dans les autres jeu pendant 10 km avec ton barda sur le dos et ton arme de 3 kg, DOD est réaliste.
mes maps préféré sont Flash, Avalanche, Jagd. je ne joue que la classe US avec la thomson.
je recommande vivement ce jeu à tout joueur voulant un vrai jeu sérieu WW2 de FPS.

I highly recommend this to any shooter fanatic and especially people that enjoy WW2 shooters. It's really polished and runs well. There's an active player base and it's a hectic game. I've played the Goldsource based version before and this is a great evolution(or continuation) of the team based shooter style.
ui

One of Valve's first World War II multiplayer video games, born as a graphically and physically better version of its predecessor Day of Defeat.

A game that was quite successful, if it were not for many negative things that unfortunately this game has and I will list them for my personal experience:

1) [u]excessively high recoil[/u]
Each weapon has a recoil that makes it difficult to control and also heavily influences its accuracy. To have more control, you must either kneel or even lie down, in short, you must try to be less mobile as possible but in this way you risk being an easy target. Also, it seems that others have no problem taking headshots with that recoil in full motion, hinting that they use cheats to control weapons.

2) [u]The neglect of the players[/u]
You try desperately to cover or capture an objective and expect others to do the same, while instead they ignore you or avoid helping you because they "have to farm kills" in their own way. And so you see them running, unaware of the imminent danger, only to die miserably. In short, a game based on cooperation, which has now become a game only for shooting. At least they hit something!

3) [u]The abuse of power or the absence of administrators[/u]
Unfortunately the game does not have official servers, but only community servers, of which most of the administrators are absent and therefore their servers are kept on to allow any unfortunate without a shred of loyalty to get into it, or they immediately kick out anyone they think is annoying or disrespectful of their "hard and fast rules." An example: I found a cheater that blatantly prefired me because he could see me through walls, so he used wallhack, and, despite I had insisted that he was kicked out of the server, "I" was been kicked out of the server just because I got nervous and scolded the cheater several times. In short, these servers are not to be taken so lightly and you end up at the mercy of the administrators.

4) [u]Old and abandoned game? So, let's use the cheats!![/u]
What can I say? As long as a videogame is dead and that's a good reason to cheat because either VAC or Valve doesn't take serious action.

In a nutshell, although it is a beautiful game because it has a certain stylistic charm and good game mechanics, it is so abandoned and so obsolete that it is not even worth trying to play it. It just makes you sick and you just want to let it rot even more

Day of Defeat: Source – сиквел к моду Half-Life, Day of Defeat. Работает на движке Half-Life 2, Source, и, подобно Counter Strike: Source, придерживается оригинальной формулы, внося несколько незначительных доработок в геймплей.Похвалы удостоились графика и атмосферный, стратегический геймплей

Day of Defeat was overshadowed at its release by the marketing efforts of other major developers and publishers pushing their own WW2 shooters, so it never really took off in terms of popularity. And that's a shame, because it was (and is) a very fun game. It offers its own charming take on chaotic WW2 era urban combat.

It runs exceptionally well on everything from a cardboard cutout PC to the latest and greatest system, and the combat is action packed. Unfortunately a full lobby isn't always easy to come by, at least if you want a server with a low ping connection. Though the Russian community on the game is still quite vibrant (and quite hilariously, if you have it in you to go play with them), most everyone else will usually find empty servers, with maybe 2 or 3 having a playable population.

DoD: Source is just one of those games that I wish had taken off, but never quite did. Still you can have some fun with it. Just grab it on sale during one of the Steam sales throughout the year and enjoy it from time to time. Just don't expect a competitive community comparable to modern CS:GO, CoD, or whatever.

Rating: Solid B game, hindered by a tiny active community.
